And so we feel that we've always said the marketing has a lag, the incremental marketing, there's a lag in terms of when we input it and the results that we're getting. But we see that the plan is working, and we certainly see that we're taking a very strategic approach in terms of marketing spend versus optimal levels. Consistent quality investment in media continues to be one of the strongest drivers of our business, enabling us to generate those -- that revenue. We look at each market, how many weeks of consumer engagement there is. The goal over time is to apply the right pressure in the right way to each of our brands and each of the segments that you mentioned which is developed, developing and emerging. And the system alignment in our bottling system is matching our alignments with investment -- I'm sorry, with capabilities execution, output development, cooler placement, et cetera. So we're pleased with what we see there. And of course, all of this being said, we have a volatile macroeconomic environment, which obviously is not getting any better anytime soon. We realized that the global growth for 2015 is projected to be below last year. And even that, having said that, the disposable incomes are even lagging the growth rates that are projected. So yes, but in general, that's how I would frame your question. And both James and I and Kathy believe that the incremental and better marketing is certainly giving us the results in terms of the top line -- currency neutral comparable top line growth.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Steve Powers of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Steve Powers of UBS.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. I actually want to talk a little bit more about the National Product Supply System that James detailed. And I guess, specifically, maybe Muhtar or James, could you talk more about the governance process there and the makeup of the managing board? A
componenttext: Great. I actually want to talk a little bit more about the National Product Supply System that James detailed. And I guess, specifically, maybe Muhtar or James, could you talk more about the governance process there and the makeup of the managing board? As I understand it, there are 5 voting members, CCR, Coke North America; and then the 3 bottlers, Consolidated, UNITED and Swire. And I guess I'm curious as to how you ensure that tough decisions get made in that structure and implemented in that structure. Do you need unanimous consents? Is it majority rules? And if there isn't unanimous consent or support for a given measure, what gives the NPSG the power to enforce successful implementation?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. What we said again at the beginning of this journey back 3, 4 years ago is that we said that we have an intention to create a system in the United States that can benefit from the local empowerment in each of the communities in the markets
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. What we said again at the beginning of this journey back 3, 4 years ago is that we said that we have an intention to create a system in the United States that can benefit from the local empowerment in each of the communities in the markets that have built our business so successfully over the last 130 years. The franchise system, the alignment that, that brings, the value and trust between us and our bottling partners. But at the same time, create the mechanism, so to speak, the processes, flexible processes in the marketplace whether it be information systems, whether it be the customer management system so that we can speak with one voice to customers, coast to coast, in the United States and the National Product Supply System. All of those negotiations with our expanding bottlers took some time to achieve. They are all achieved, that's why we're progressing with rapid -- rapidly with our refranchising program, which is working very well because when we have those processes in place, we can refranchise with confidence and speed and have the business continue to generate the results and the growth that we are seeing in revenue, particularly in the United States of America. And the United States nonalcoholic beverage business is healthy. It is growing in revenues and cent -- dollars and cents. And that's the really important measure, important element that I want to leave with you. But more in -- just to add more color and flavor to the National Product Supply System question that you had in terms of the governance model, I'll ask James to comment further and give you more insights. James?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think just specifically on governance, it's not going to be around unanimity. It's going to be based on the driving of the business case. Everyone is committed to doing what is economically the most rational answer for the system. Again, this is --
componenttext: Yes. I think just specifically on governance, it's not going to be around unanimity. It's going to be based on the driving of the business case. Everyone is committed to doing what is economically the most rational answer for the system. Again, this is -- when it comes to the national issues, it's not necessarily the management of each local plant, which will remain the job of each of the participating bottlers or CCNA.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Steve, does that address your question?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sorry, I was on mute. No, that does help. But I guess, James, just to follow up, if there is friction on a given issue or if there's debate about what is in the best sort of economic interest of the system, what's the tiebreaker? How does the sort of
componenttext: Yes. Sorry, I was on mute. No, that does help. But I guess, James, just to follow up, if there is friction on a given issue or if there's debate about what is in the best sort of economic interest of the system, what's the tiebreaker? How does the sort of the majority view get pushed through?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're not laying out the precise mechanic, but I can tell you that there's not going to be a full consensus required for every decision. It's going to be a large majority. And if they support the economic case, then that's what's going to -- that's going
componenttext: We're not laying out the precise mechanic, but I can tell you that there's not going to be a full consensus required for every decision. It's going to be a large majority. And if they support the economic case, then that's what's going to -- that's going to move forward. So we're not creating a system that can become blocked. We're creating a system that's focused on the best economics of the system in North America, and there are mechanisms for that to go forward.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. There are mechanisms in place to break a tie?
componenttext: Great. There are mechanisms in place to break a tie?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Correct.
componenttext: Correct.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess, I was hoping to get a little bit more color in your performance in Europe this quarter. So 4% volume growth, certainly, an improvement there. You called out some of the factors to green shoots in Europe. You've got the favorable weather condition
componenttext: I guess, I was hoping to get a little bit more color in your performance in Europe this quarter. So 4% volume growth, certainly, an improvement there. You called out some of the factors to green shoots in Europe. You've got the favorable weather conditions as well as the marketing spending step-up. So number 1, can you just talk about a little bit more behind what really drove the volume improvement? How sustainable those improvements are in terms of volume? And then, if you think about price/mix performance in Europe, kind of flattish performance in a more developed market, so how should we think about that number? How much was that geographic mix? And are you seeing actual price realization in some of the markets? Understanding that obviously, it's a tough deflationary market there.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Judy, thanks. This is Muhtar. Unit cases, as you said, did grow 4% in the quarter in Europe. They were cycling a minus 5 from prior year and was -- and sparkling was up as well as stills growing faster than sparkling in Western Europe. And so -- and
componenttext: Yes, Judy, thanks. This is Muhtar. Unit cases, as you said, did grow 4% in the quarter in Europe. They were cycling a minus 5 from prior year and was -- and sparkling was up as well as stills growing faster than sparkling in Western Europe. And so -- and then our concentrate sales did trail also the unit cases in Western Europe as it did for the whole company. And I'll ask -- and we were pleased with the results, and certainly again some early results from the marketing, but more to come. And I'll ask James to add more color to that. James?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, thanks, Muhtar. As Muhtar referenced it, we were cycling a pretty poor quarter from last year. So I think it was a favorable comparison, and we had strong results from very favorable weather in the southern and the central part of Europe, but I would
componenttext: Yes, thanks, Muhtar. As Muhtar referenced it, we were cycling a pretty poor quarter from last year. So I think it was a favorable comparison, and we had strong results from very favorable weather in the southern and the central part of Europe, but I wouldn't read too much in to the 1 quarter. I think if you look at the longer-term trends, you can see that we're getting some volume growth in the year-to-date with the price/mixes bouncing around flat. I think it's important to recognize 2 things as it comes to price/mix in the case of Europe. One is the general deflationary nature of the European market. Retail pricing is 0 to 1, at best in general. And then secondly, it's worth remembering that the starting point of pricing in Europe is in comparison to the U.S. higher. So the opportunity is to drive price/mix on a sustained long-term basis in the sense we've already captured some of that in Europe, and we will be chasing that in the U.S. So I don't think we'll see the same sort of price/mix over time in Europe given our starting point.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Bryan Spillane of Bank of America.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Kathy, just a question for you and just thinking about some of the, I guess, the macro drivers of the P&L as we move into the fourth quarter and maybe beyond into '16. Other income this quarter was an expense, that at all related to the euro bond gain tha
componenttext: Kathy, just a question for you and just thinking about some of the, I guess, the macro drivers of the P&L as we move into the fourth quarter and maybe beyond into '16. Other income this quarter was an expense, that at all related to the euro bond gain that you had in the first half, and how we think about lapping that next year? FX, the negative effect on operating income is greater in the fourth quarter than it will be in the -- than it was in the third quarter. So should we think about FX carrying into '16? And then in terms of structural change, I guess, with Germany now essentially being contributed to the partnership or the new entity in Europe, that will be a structural change for next year. But just anything we should be thinking about in terms of changes in the structural change component of modeling, I guess, going into the fourth quarter and maybe into next year would be helpful.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, thanks, Bryan. So the -- for foreign exchange for next year, remember, we've said that for our hard currencies, we are hedged. And so our real exposure is around our emerging currencies. Now that being said, we do have to cycle that euro debt bond o
componenttext: Sure, thanks, Bryan. So the -- for foreign exchange for next year, remember, we've said that for our hard currencies, we are hedged. And so our real exposure is around our emerging currencies. Now that being said, we do have to cycle that euro debt bond offering, which impacted the first and second quarter of this year. And for the full year, it was about 3 points benefit to us, so we do have to cycle that next year on top of just the change in the rates and probably a more difficult currency environment going forward. So we will give more color on currency in February when we give our full year results for 2016, but our issue is really going to be around the amazing -- the emerging markets where we've just -- it's not cost effective to hedge prior -- more than about a quarter at a time. And then in terms of the structural impact, yes, Germany will be a structural impact next year. Obviously, we'll continue with the North America refranchising, so that will still have a significant impact in North America. And there may be some slight impacts from whenever the things -- Africa closes the -- Africa transaction closes, but the majority of it will be the Germany transaction and the North America refranchising.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just with the Africa JV, do we still expect that, that will close before the end of the year? Or is there any update on timing there?
componenttext: Okay. And just with the Africa JV, do we still expect that, that will close before the end of the year? Or is there any update on timing there?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I want to -- Bryan, this is Muhtar. What I'd say is that it's in the regulatory approval process, and that's all I would say right now. And then we expect it to close sometime over the next sort of 3 to 4 months. That's what I would say.
componenttext: Yes, I want to -- Bryan, this is Muhtar. What I'd say is that it's in the regulatory approval process, and that's all I would say right now. And then we expect it to close sometime over the next sort of 3 to 4 months. That's what I would say.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question is from Ali Dibadj of Bernstein.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a few things. One is I was hoping you could set people just more at ease around the closure of the gap in unit case volume to concentrate sales. Getting a lot of questions there. If that -- look,  if you're really comfortable with that, and if that's
componenttext: Just a few things. One is I was hoping you could set people just more at ease around the closure of the gap in unit case volume to concentrate sales. Getting a lot of questions there. If that -- look,  if you're really comfortable with that, and if that's the case, that, that closes for all the regions of the world, it certainly does look like there's an inflection point on top line. But are we now comfortable enough to also start talking a little bit about perhaps a crossover point or inflection point in the productivity savings being higher than reinvestment rate as well, so margins can also look like they're expanding? It looks like you had flat operating margins here, including the FX effects there, but that's better than it's been in a little while as well. So can we clarify and then give us a sense on a margin inflection potential as well?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So unit cases to concentrate shipments. That's really impacted by Asia Pacific and Latin America. If you look at Latin America on a year-to-date basis, they are absolutely in line. And with Asia Pacific, on a year-to-date basis, we expect them to be
componenttext: Sure. So unit cases to concentrate shipments. That's really impacted by Asia Pacific and Latin America. If you look at Latin America on a year-to-date basis, they are absolutely in line. And with Asia Pacific, on a year-to-date basis, we expect them to be generally in line. So there's really no story there in terms of that gap. When you -- then moving on to productivity, so the productivity initiative, obviously, we are seeing some benefit from productivity. There is -- in our margins, there is an impact in our margins from, basically, the structural changes. So if you would exclude structural changes, the -- so gross margins and operating margins would be higher, and you would see margin expansion. When you look at the third quarter, when you look at the set of leverage, so we are getting some productivity, but we also have an impact from timing of the DME from -- basically, from prior year that's impacting that timing from this year that, by the way, turns around in the fourth quarter. So I think there are a lot of puts and takes going on around productivity. You are seeing some productivity coming through. We are -- we continue to reinvest behind our brands though. But our margin expansion is masked right now by currency and structural. So if you pull those 2 things out, you see very good margin expansion.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And I'll just add 1 point, Ali. I think what we saw in this past quarter in terms of operating margin expansion on a currency neutral comparable basis of about 100 basis points, we were pleased with that expansion. Now the key is to do everything we can t
componenttext: And I'll just add 1 point, Ali. I think what we saw in this past quarter in terms of operating margin expansion on a currency neutral comparable basis of about 100 basis points, we were pleased with that expansion. Now the key is to do everything we can to continue and ensure that we execute fully on the 5 strategic points going forward, so that we can continue to improve our trajectory.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. That's helpful. Just from a structural perspective as you mentioned it, one of the big changes, obviously, in the marketplace is the ABI SAB deal, which is agreed upon, I guess. Can you talk a little bit about any of the deal implications to y
componenttext: Okay, okay. That's helpful. Just from a structural perspective as you mentioned it, one of the big changes, obviously, in the marketplace is the ABI SAB deal, which is agreed upon, I guess. Can you talk a little bit about any of the deal implications to you structurally in that context? For instance, would you let them produce both for you and the blue system? Is that something you can shed a little bit of light on as now it's an agreed-upon deal, it sounds like?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ali, we will not comment on any specific matters related to our customers, bottlers or any M&A matters, so I'll just leave it at that.
componenttext: Ali, we will not comment on any specific matters related to our customers, bottlers or any M&A matters, so I'll just leave it at that.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from John Faucher of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Our next question is from John Faucher of JPMorgan.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to go back and sort of a little bit of a follow-up to Steve's question. If I look at Slide 10 in the handouts, if I look at North America, you guys are fragmenting that sort of last piece to market, that last piece of the route to market, and then
componenttext: I want to go back and sort of a little bit of a follow-up to Steve's question. If I look at Slide 10 in the handouts, if I look at North America, you guys are fragmenting that sort of last piece to market, that last piece of the route to market, and then also to some extent, the manufacturing piece. Yet you're telling us on the flip side, as we look at Europe, as you create this sort of wall that goes across Europe of all one big bottler, that consolidation is something that seems to be the right thing for Europe. So can you talk a little bit about why fragmenting North America yet consolidating Europe at the same time, those are both the right strategies when they -- I don't want to say they're diametrically opposed, but at least say appear to be somewhat in conflict with each other.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, this is Muhtar. Actually, they're not in conflict at all. They're basically very complementary to our strategy, which is to ensure that we have the local touch and we have also the scale and we have the processes to meet customer demands and custome
componenttext: John, this is Muhtar. Actually, they're not in conflict at all. They're basically very complementary to our strategy, which is to ensure that we have the local touch and we have also the scale and we have the processes to meet customer demands and customer partnerships. And in the United States, we've actually not -- you mentioned the word fragmented. We have a national customer management system. We have a national production system. We have a national information system that is basically all with their own governance models, and they're very fluid and very flexible to suit the needs of the business today. And then at the same time, every piece of the United States that has those elements really are -- have enough size for scale, and then we have the much smaller -- the smaller distributor bottling system that also -- the smaller guys are doing a great job in growing the business for us. And then in Europe, basically what we have is the customer landscape in Europe is much, much more concentrated in Western Europe, where just a handful of customers account for a very large portion of the total future consumption, the retail business in Europe. And therefore, when you look at what we've created in Western Europe, it basically suits the -- our future needs in terms of working proactively with our customer partners, and also it gives the scale and also it gives the local touch in each of the markets. So from that perspective, just like we're -- what we've done in Japan, just like what we've done in South Africa, just like in large markets I'm talking about, it basically very much aligns it to our strategy in how you think about what we're doing in the marketplace.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. If I can just ask a follow-up. I guess, you talked about local touch with the smaller local bottlers in the U.S. and then you also talked about local touch in Europe. And I guess -- again, just to play devil's advocate here, aren't you moving away f
componenttext: Okay. If I can just ask a follow-up. I guess, you talked about local touch with the smaller local bottlers in the U.S. and then you also talked about local touch in Europe. And I guess -- again, just to play devil's advocate here, aren't you moving away from the local -- I realize you're going to try and keep some of the local pieces through the new bottling entity. But it seems to me that's moving less local. So I guess, it sounds like you're trying to have it both ways. And I guess, I'm just not following why one is so dramatically better than the other. Is it just simply sort of the smaller account piece on the U.S. side that creates the difference here?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, there's -- the customer base in the United States and Western Europe is very, very different in terms of how it's structured. And so we follow the customer -- the needs of the customer, what matters. We follow the scale, we follow the necessity for
componenttext: Well, there's -- the customer base in the United States and Western Europe is very, very different in terms of how it's structured. And so we follow the customer -- the needs of the customer, what matters. We follow the scale, we follow the necessity for speed, and we feel that the model that is being created in Western Europe will serve us very well for the next decade and beyond. And the same thing goes for the United States. It is proving that it is serving us very well in terms of getting us to scale, in terms of getting us the cost in production and cost of goods sold but at the same time, retaining the local touch and retaining the local element that is really important in our business. Both of those are valid for Europe and for Western Europe and for Japan and for South Africa and for the United States or wherever else you see us create a better bottling system.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Vivien Azer of Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Our next question is from Vivien Azer of Cowen & Company.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Muhtar, I wanted to circle back on the comment that you made about the health of the U.S. LRB category. I mean, clearly that's apparent on the still side of the business. But as I look at the syndicated data for carbonated beverages in the United States,
componenttext: Muhtar, I wanted to circle back on the comment that you made about the health of the U.S. LRB category. I mean, clearly that's apparent on the still side of the business. But as I look at the syndicated data for carbonated beverages in the United States, it does look like the category is softening a bit, and I think your revenues were down 3 out of the last 4 months. So I was hoping you could comment on the evolution of the U.S. CSD side, and the demand elasticities and how they're evolving please?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think based on -- what we are seeing is we're able to generate revenue growth both from the sparking category very much so as well as in the still side and therefore, that's what my comment referred to. This is not just 1 quarter, this is multiple
componenttext: Well, I think based on -- what we are seeing is we're able to generate revenue growth both from the sparking category very much so as well as in the still side and therefore, that's what my comment referred to. This is not just 1 quarter, this is multiple quarters. And at the same time, inside that LRB category, that is showing very good resilience in terms of both price elasticity, price discipline, approach with customers, generating value for our customers, both on the sparkling side as well as in large and small customers in the still side. We're also seeing that we're -- this is the 22nd consecutive quarter of us gaining value share in the marketplace in North America. And so -- and then the mix is really working for us in terms of generating the marketing is -- where the North American market is the first market where we've started putting -- employing incremental marketing. Better marketing is generating also positive results for us in terms of the revenue growth from sparkling-derived particularly -- purely from sparkling as well as from the still side of the business. And James, do you want to add any color to that?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, I mean, if you take a look at how we're driving the sparkling business, you can look at the transaction packages, which represent about 15% of the volume, and they're growing still again this quarter into double digits. So we're very pleased
componenttext: Yes, I think, I mean, if you take a look at how we're driving the sparkling business, you can look at the transaction packages, which represent about 15% of the volume, and they're growing still again this quarter into double digits. So we're very pleased with the marketing, and the OBPPC approach is driving positive revenue growth to sparkling on a consistent basis.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bill Marshall of Barclays.
componenttext: The next question is from Bill Marshall of Barclays.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if I could ask you about the recent vote in Mexico. It looks like there's a proposal to reduce the tax on soda by about half on products with 5 grams of sugar or less per 100 milliliters. So first, I was just wondering what you thought abo
componenttext: I was wondering if I could ask you about the recent vote in Mexico. It looks like there's a proposal to reduce the tax on soda by about half on products with 5 grams of sugar or less per 100 milliliters. So first, I was just wondering what you thought about the prospects of that? If you could give us any clarity on what percentage of your portfolio that would cover. And then, if we just think about it from a high level, and maybe James, you could give us some color in a number of these markets, if we look at the Mexican soda tax as a template for the rest of the world, does this suggest any tempering of how some of the regulatory authorities are looking at the category broadly speaking?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So of course, we need to wait and see whether the recent vote produces the act of law by the end of the process. It's only gone through one of the stages. So we'll see where that ends up. Obviously, we are in favor of reductions in discriminatory taxes. I
componenttext: So of course, we need to wait and see whether the recent vote produces the act of law by the end of the process. It's only gone through one of the stages. So we'll see where that ends up. Obviously, we are in favor of reductions in discriminatory taxes. I think as we look out on how that has impacted the vote and how that's being viewed and it will be used as a case study around the world. The data we have, so far, is the impact of the tax was to bring down about 6 calories from the Mexican diet by the end of the process. So we're conscious that obesity is a crisis. We know we need to play a role. We don't think that this is the silver bullet that anyone was looking for, and we think that the -- much more work needs to be done if indeed a solution is to be brought to bear on the whole obesity crisis, in which overconsumption of anything including soft drinks would be a contributor and are part of the problem. So we'll see where this tax ends up. I mean, clearly taxing diets and lights [ph] doesn't seem to be the right way forward. And therefore, if this tax -- if this measure goes through, I think it would be positive.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And the last question is from Nik Modi of RBC.
componenttext: And the last question is from Nik Modi of RBC.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on Asia, perhaps you can provide a little bit of context. It looks like that business may not be performing as well as you like on a -- broadly speaking. Is this a portfolio issue? I mean, can you just talk a little bit about what's
componenttext: Just a quick question on Asia, perhaps you can provide a little bit of context. It looks like that business may not be performing as well as you like on a -- broadly speaking. Is this a portfolio issue? I mean, can you just talk a little bit about what's going on across that region so we can just think about that as we go into 2016?

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, Nik, I'll just say very broadly at a high level, we're pleased with our performance in China. Obviously, a lot of noise around China these days, but we have, as mentioned earlier in the script, we have an all-time high share for brand Coke in
componenttext: Yes, I mean, Nik, I'll just say very broadly at a high level, we're pleased with our performance in China. Obviously, a lot of noise around China these days, but we have, as mentioned earlier in the script, we have an all-time high share for brand Coke in China. We have -- and we're growing in China, and we're gaining share in China, and we're investing in China. And the same goes for India, 2 of the very large markets in Asia. Certainly pleased with the results there. We had some weather-related issues in the quarter before, but we're coming back, and the business is really coming back and performing much better in India. And so overall, I think -- and then in Japan, we're seeing some green shoots in terms of disposable incomes. We're very early still to call it any color. But overall, I'd say -- and then obviously back in south -- Australasia, the economy was very much related to commodities and it has suffered, and we're seeing the macro spillover from that. But I'd say overall, in this past quarter, we're happy with the results in the big economies and then -- and now realizing -- recognizing that we've got more work to do, and that's how I would leave it.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you. I would now like to turn the call back to Muhtar Kent for closing remarks.
componenttext: Thank you. I would now like to turn the call back to Muhtar Kent for closing remarks.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, James, Kathy and Tim. So in summary, our company has undergone a substantial amount of change over the past 10 to 12 months. And our third quarter results demonstrate continued progress against our 5 strategic initiatives. The long-term dynamic
componenttext:
Thank you, James, Kathy and Tim. So in summary, our company has undergone a substantial amount of change over the past 10 to 12 months. And our third quarter results demonstrate continued progress against our 5 strategic initiatives. The long-term dynamics of our industry remain promising, and we absolutely believe that The Coca-Cola Company and the Coca-Cola system is best positioned to capture that growth in nonalcoholic beverages and to deliver long-term value to our shareholders.
As always, we thank you for your interest, your investment in our company and for joining us this morning.

headline: The Coca-Cola Company, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And that concludes today's call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: And that concludes today's call. Thank you for your participation. You may now disconnect.
